verses.text: The word of the LORD came to Jeremiah a second time, while he was still shut up in the court of the guard:
verses.comment: Jeremiah receives divine revelation during imprisonment, highlighting God's provision in adversity. 'Court of the guard' suggests Jeremiah is in confinement for prophesying truth.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD who made the earth, the LORD who formed it to establish it—his name is the LORD:
verses.comment: God identifies Himself as Creator. This grounds the following promises in His sovereign power and authority.

verses.text: Call to me and I will answer you, and will tell you great and inaccessible things that you have not known.
verses.comment: Encouragement to prayer and revelation; 'inaccessible things' refers to divine mysteries, prefiguring deeper revelation in New Testament teachings.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, concerning the houses of this city and the houses of the kings of Judah that are torn down to defend against the siege mounds and sword:
verses.comment: Jerusalem's buildings are being destroyed for defense—symbolizing the desperate situation.

verses.text: They are coming in to fight against the Chaldeans, but to fill these houses with the dead bodies of people whom I have struck down in my anger and my wrath, for I have hidden my face from this city because of all their evil.
verses.comment: God's judgment results in death and devastation due to persistent sin, showing the consequences of unrepentance.

verses.text: Behold, I will bring to it health and healing, and I will heal them and reveal to them the abundance of peace and truth.
verses.comment: Transition from judgment to restoration; both physical and spiritual healing are promised, prefiguring ultimate reconciliation in Christ.

verses.text: I will restore the fortunes of Judah and the fortunes of Israel, and rebuild them as at the beginning.
verses.comment: God plans to reunite and restore both Judah and Israel, emphasizing total renewal reminiscent of Eden.

verses.text: I will cleanse them from all the guilt of their sins against me, and I will forgive all their sins of rebellion against me.
verses.comment: Promise of both cleansing and forgiveness, echoing sacramental and spiritual restoration. Strong link to messianic prophecy regarding forgiveness of sins.

verses.text: This city will be to me a name of joy, a praise and glory before all the nations of the earth who will hear of all the good that I do for them; and they shall fear and tremble because of all the goodness and peace that I provide for it.
verses.comment: Jerusalem's restoration serves as a witness to the world of God's faithfulness, prefiguring the gathering of the nations in eschatological fulfillment.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: In this place, of which you say, 'It is desolate, without man or beast,' in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem that are deserted, without man or inhabitant or beast, there shall be heard again
verses.comment: Desolation is not permanent; promise of future restoration. Emphasizes that even utter ruin can become a source of hope.

verses.text: the voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the groom and the voice of the bride, the voices of those who sing, 'Give thanks to the LORD of hosts, for the LORD is good, for his steadfast love endures forever,' as they bring offerings of thanksgiving into the house of the LORD. For I will restore the fortunes of the land as at first, says the LORD.
verses.comment: Return of celebration and worship points to liturgical restoration. The image of the 'bride and groom' anticipates New Testament imagery of Christ and the Church (cf. Rev. 19:7).

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: In this place that is waste, without man or beast, in all its cities there shall again be dwellings for shepherds resting their flocks.
verses.comment: Shepherd imagery recalls God’s care, and prophecy of restoration. This anticipates both literal return and the spiritual gathering of God’s people.

verses.text: In the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the Shephelah, and in the cities of the Negev, in the land of Benjamin, in the places around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, flocks shall again pass under the hands of the one who counts them, says the LORD.
verses.comment: Restoration is comprehensive across all regions. 'Passing under the hands' references the shepherd's careful oversight, foreshadowing the coming Messianic shepherd.

verses.text: Behold, the days are coming, declares the LORD, when I will fulfill the good promise that I made to the house of Israel and the house of Judah.
verses.comment: 'The days are coming' marks a pivotal messianic prophecy, promising fulfillment to both Israel and Judah—unity implied in future blessing.

verses.text: In those days and at that time I will cause a righteous Branch to spring up for David, and he shall execute justice and righteousness in the land.
verses.comment: Direct messianic prophecy; 'Branch' is a symbol of the coming Christ. The Davidic kingdom is reaffirmed, connecting Old Testament hopes to New Testament fulfillment in Jesus.

verses.text: In those days Judah will be saved, and Jerusalem will dwell securely. And this is the name by which it will be called: 'The LORD is our righteousness.'
verses.comment: 'The LORD is our righteousness' both applies to the city and foreshadows the imputed righteousness received through Christ. Note spiritual and communal security promised.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD: David will never lack a man to sit on the throne of the house of Israel;
verses.comment: Unbroken Davidic lineage points towards perpetual kingship, interpreted spiritually in Christ's everlasting reign.

verses.text: and the Levitical priests will never lack a man before me to offer burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings, and to make sacrifices continually.
verses.comment: Perpetual priesthood denotes ongoing sacrificial worship. Interpreted as foreshadowing the enduring liturgical ministry seen in New Testament worship.

verses.text: And the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah:
verses.comment: Signifies another divine statement, emphasizing prophetic authority.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: If you can break my covenant with the day and my covenant with the night, so that day and night no longer come at their appointed time,
verses.comment: God uses the regular order of creation to assert the unbreakable nature of His covenant promises.

verses.text: then also my covenant with David my servant may be broken, so that he will not have a son to reign on his throne, and my covenant with my ministers, the Levites.
verses.comment: God’s covenant with David and the priesthood is as steadfast as creation itself. Theologically, this affirms succession and continuity.

verses.text: As the host of heaven cannot be numbered and the sands of the sea cannot be measured, so I will multiply the descendants of David my servant and the Levitical priests who minister to me.
verses.comment: Abundant offspring connects Abrahamic, Davidic, and priestly promises, foreshadowing the universal, united people of God.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came to Jeremiah:
verses.comment: Signals yet another revelation, further reinforcing the prophecy's certainty.

verses.text: Have you not observed what these people are saying: 'The LORD has rejected the two families that he chose'? Thus they despise my people, so that they are no longer a nation in their sight.
verses.comment: Echoes doubts of the faithless. 'Two families' refers to Israel and Judah or Davidic and priestly lines. God will affirm their ongoing chosenness.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: If I have not established my covenant with day and night and the fixed order of heaven and earth,
verses.comment: Physical creation is used to reinforce the reliability of God’s covenant with His people. God’s faithfulness is unchanging.

verses.text: then I will reject the descendants of Jacob and David my servant, and will not choose one of his offspring to rule over the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. For I will restore their fortunes and have compassion on them.
verses.comment: Ends with assurance: restoration and mercy are certain. Connects the patriarchal, Davidic, and priestly promises, pointing to a unified, apostolic leadership and compassion for God’s people.
